teaser.content:
The necropolis of Ayamonte (Huelva, Spain) was first discovered in 2007 and belongs to the westernmost known Phoenician colony of the first wave of expansion in the 8th c. BC.
The estuary of the Guadiana into the Atlantic Ocean offered protected anchorage sites and ideal requirements for the development of a settlement and thus the exchange with indigenous trader partners of the hinterland rich in resources. A Spanish-German project 'The Phoenician necropolis of Ayamonte (Huleva, Andalusia, Spain)' investigated the settlement starting in 2013.

For the documentation of the excavation iDAI.field was used, a relational FileMaker-database management system that had been developed by the IT department of the DAI in cooperation with the Cologne Digital Archaeology Laboratory (University of Cologne, previously “Research Archive for Ancient Sculpture”) from 2006 onwards. It has been in us by various archaeological field research projects of differing time periods and geographical regions. The Ayamonte excavation data was migrated into the newly conceptionalized version of iDAI.field of 2016 (also called “iDAI.field 2”), which is based on Open Source and web technologies, can be used freely (https://field.dainst.org) and allows an online publication of the archaeological databases through the iDAI.field Web component.

articles.headline: New MOOC: Instruction for the archaeological drawing of ceramic sherds

teaser.content:
Register for the Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) Instruction for the archaeological drawing of ceramic sherds on iDAI.tutorials. The course and resources will continuously be updated and supported by the project KulturGutRetter as well as the Archaeological Heritage Network (ArcHerNet). The autodidactic course can be completed at any time without cost in either English or Arabic.

Just like photographs, archaeological drawings form an integral part of the visual documentation of excavations and archaeological objects. This course is an introduction to the drawing of pottery sherds and vessels in archaeology. It teaches basic tools and abilities to students of archaeology and illustrators that are needed to draw pottery by hand. This guideline is based on the experiences of numerous excavations in various countries over the years. The participants will get to know the necessary tools and materials and will learn to draw simple pottery profiles and decorative patterns.

articles.headline: The iDAI.world in light of the new digital policies of the Federal Republic of Germany

teaser.content:
With the second Open-Data-Directive the federal government of Germany is implementing the revised EU directive 2019/1024 (Directive on open data and the reuse of public-sector information) of the year 2019 into national policy.
Further, an amendment to Section 12a of the E-Government Act is intended to achieve the most comprehensive publication of open federal data.

A necessary cornerstone for digital information infrastructure of the German Archaeological Institute was laid out in the 90s at the Research Archive for Ancient Sculpture of the University of Cologne. The iDAI.world emerged from this as a grown and complex digital offer, on which numerous institutions and scientists have cooperated. A working group has evaluated how the iDAI.world finds its place against the backdrop of these new digital laws.

To Geoserver project >

The new archaeological map of Pergamon represents all known archaeological building remains. The map is an updated and extended version of the map of Pergamon published in 1973. Current excavations of the Pergamon Excavation Project and the Museum Bergama are shown, but also older excavations from the 1930s and 1950s on the Musalla Mezarlığı.

The publication of the new archaeological map of Pergamon is an important milestone in the study of the ancient metropolis. For the first time since 1973 a new cartographic basis for the ancient city of Pergamon is available. The new map represents all known archaeological remains. Excavations, for example, from the 1930s and 1950s at the Musalla Mezarlığı or the excavations of the Bergama Museum over the last fifteen years have now also been included.

articles.headline: Tuna el-Gebel: Celebrating with the dead' and the Krause archive on the iDAI.world

teaser.content:
To project and data >

iDAI.objects/Arachne is proud to present new datasets and images from an external project 'Tuna el-Gebel: Celebrating with the dead' and the Krause Archive.

Temples, houses, and tombs, animal worship and human necropolis – Tuna el-Gebel is a fascinating site located about 270 km south of Cairo and 10 km west of the ancient city of Hermopolis Magna, a metropolis of Middle Egypt. Most of the buildings belong to the Ptolemaic and Roman periods between 300 BC and 300 AD.

Some of the tomb houses excavated by Sami Gabra as well as their associated parts of buildings with wall paintings, photographically documented by Bernd Harald Krause, are now digitally available as datasets in Arachne.

articles.headline: EC Chronoi: The multilingualism of time

teaser.content:
The iDAI.world now also contains a new project called „The multilingualism of time“ that has been conducted in cooperation with the Einstein Center Chronoi, aiming at developing a tool that is able to normalize and detect time expressions in archaeological literature of varying source languages. This was done by developing a multilingual corpus of archaeological texts, and secondly by adding period terms to an already in use time parser, in this case Heideltime.

The problem we are facing is the fact that computers cannot process period terms in the same way as human beings. Many temporal terms are simply a relative expression to a given date and time, which is understandable to a human being by context. Computers need absolute temporal terms such as a definite year or date. Time periods pose a similar problem as the definition is not always the same in each region of the world. It is necessary to use a time parser that can detect a temporal term and thus normalized it, e.g. give it a numerical value.

articles.headline: Scholars, excavators and art dealers' - Quarantine Special: Gerhard's Odyssey

teaser.content:
Correspondence of Emil Braun and Eduard Gerhard during a cholera outbreak in 1836-1837

The corona crisis shows well how a pandemic can rule the world for months or even years as the measures for its containment and the fight against its consequences not only influence politics and economics but also change people’s every day lives and outlook on matters.
The 19th century is clouded over by extensive epidemics that were caused by viral or bacterial infections. Due to Europe-wide travel connections, these epidemics spread over many cities and states. Large cities, especially those with a port, open so-called cordons for restriction and quarantine facilities where travellers had to go into quarantine.
The letter exchange between Eduard Gerhard, cofounder as well as first secretary of the Instituto di Correspondenza Archeologica in Rome and Emil Braun, who was Gerhard’s assistant from 1833 onwards, deputy director of the Instituto and confidante, spans over the cholera wave between the years 1836 to 1837.

This online catalog accompanies the book Sea Shells in the Mountains and Llamas on the Coast: The Economy of the Paracas Culture (800 to 200 BC) in Southern Peru (Mader 2019), published as part of the series “Research into the Archaeology of Non-European Cultures” by the German Archaeological Institute (DAI). The catalog provides data and images of archaeological finds and contexts which have been excavated since 1996 by the Nasca-Palpa Project of the DAI’s Commission for Archaeology of Non-European Cultures (KAAK).

articles.headline: New data enhanced publication: Palilia 32 - 'Large statuettes' in Medma

teaser.content:
Another publication that uses the iDAI.world systems for its catalog has appeared in the DAI's series 'Palilia'. It covers terracotta figures that used to measure from 40-60 cm, which were discovered in a large votive depot at ‚Località Calderazzo‘ located in today's Rosarno (Calabria). A scared area of the Greek colony of Medma was situated here in antiquity.

The large statuettes were produced from 550-450 BC in the same production circle as the 'Lokrian pinakes'. They were crafted by using several handformed matrices that were later put together.

A list of services that can be used online as COVID-19 resulted in the closure of all DAI libraries.
The DAI’s sixteen libraries are a key resource for the international research community. Nearly one million books on a range of specialized subjects are available for users. The DAI libraries does not only hold physical volumes but also many electronic forms of media such as ebooks, ejournals and databases.

As a special service in the present COVID19 situation, the libraries have set up an eLibrary service list for its users. The list contains links to many open access sources and temporarily available resources covering the field of archaeological sciences as well as classical and ancient studies, all accessible without financial or licensing hurdles. The list is constantly being added to.

Click here to download the elibrary service list in various languages. The PDF is free to share, so feel free to pass it on.

articles.headline: iDAI.field tutorial now available in Arabic

teaser.content: The iDAI.tutorial teaching iDAI.field is now available in Arabic as well! iDAI.field is an open access tool for field documentation developed by the German Archaeological Institute (DAI). It combines features of GIS, photo management, and database management systems in a unique and integrating manner, it aims at facilitating archaeological workflows by reducing the overhead of using multiple systems. It has an adjustable data model and is free to reuse and adjust depending on project needs. This course introduces this tool and provides the necessary basic information to help you use it for your project.

articles.headline: World's largest digital photo archive given to Sudan

teaser.content:
The archive of the German Sudan researcher Friedrich W. Hinkel (1925-2007) was digitized by the German Archaeological Institute and can now be accessed digitally through the iDAI.world. It forms a basis for a first monument register of Sudan.

On Febrary 27th 2020 German president Frank-Walter Steinmayer visited the National Museum of Sudan in Khartoum. During his visit, the president was taught about the history of Sudan and the German contributions to further research regarding Sudanese history. Amongst others, the DAI presented four projects of its recent investigations. A copy of the Friedrich-Hinkel-Research-Archiv was given to the National Corporation for Antiquities and Museums (NCAM) in presence of representatives of the Qatar Sudan Archaeological Project. The valuable archive was digitized by the head office of the DAI in Berlin and is made accessible online to the scientific public through iDAI.world. This forms a basis for a urgently needed national monument register in Sudan.

The largest catacomb of Rome, the Domitilla catacomb, with its subterranean passageway of more than 12 km, has been documented between 2006-2012 with state-of-the-art 3D laser scanning techniques. The enormous point cloud of the four stories allows the users to visit and more importantly do research in the catacomb virtually.
Until recently a general plan of the aboveground area has not been created, which allows the connection to the modern road and building orientation as well as the slightly hilly terrain model to the catacomb. This is not only important for the reconstruction of the connection between the subterranean and aboveground necropolis but also for the planning of further conservational measures such as water management and road construction.

The iDAI.world has a new addition. The Inden project page can be used as a new digital feature for the documentation documents that were created during the excavation campaigns in Inden that took place from 1965 to 1967.
The drawings of the excavation surfaces, especially the house's floor plans, as well as single sites ('Stellen'), can be inferred from Excel-tables of the Stellen-numbers. In these tables, information on the kind of site, association to larger sites (buildings, fences), location within the general excavation ('square'/ 'roll'), sheet numbers of the A3 drawings with respective positions and the name of the drawer(s), as well as inventory numbers of the finds. Surely, some inconsistencies can be found, such as twice or never used numbers, that can be explained by the lack of time and problems in communication within a large excavation but could also have become hard to identify after 50 years - as seen for some find descriptions. Some scrolls without built find sites, drawings from trenches in the west outside of the Rössener settlement and profile drawings from these trenches that mostly contained Bronze Age sites were not scanned.

The iDAI.world has improved the accessibility of the digital projects that were previously not centrally assembled. The category 'What' has been updated with a subpage showing the projects either by topic or by letter.

The DAI has created a new dainst.blog website about the elearning platform ONLAAH that focuses on African heritage and archaeology. The blog features all things going on behind the scenes and will also inform about new features.

articles.headline: New journal-viewer with new Archäologischer Anzeiger

teaser.content:
With the current issue of the Archäologischer Anzeiger the German Archaeological Institute will take an important step forward into the digital future and will draw attention to new accents for an up-to-date publication format in archaeological and classical studiesjournals.

From now on the journal’s printed version will be simultaneously accompanied by a redesigned and open access digital version in a responsive viewer format. For the first time within the field of Archaeology, the DAI-Journal-Viewer provides for the possibility of connecting and expanding articles with digital supplements or research data and will fit into the open online infrastructure of the iDAI.world, the comprehensive digital research environment of the German Archaeological Institute.

For two days, the German National Academy of Sciences Leopoldina & Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities have met in Jerusalem for a joint symposium on Computational Archaeology. The conference has reflected on the achievements of research in this field in Israel & Germany.

In the future the iDAI.world will replace the access point to all of the iDAI.world’s systems and all of its data. Although searching data through the respective systems will still be possible, a new search bar, which encompasses all of the DAI online systems, is going to allow for an easier and more integrated approach to finding the data you need. The user is given the opportunity to consider several facets when researching; topographies, objects, names, translations, archive material and concepts will be included in a single search.

The iDAI.world is divided into several categories: What, Why and How. Each of these sections will be further explained. What – What is the iDAI.world? What does it contain? Why – Why does the iDAI.world exist? What are its aims and functions? How – How does the iDAI.world reach its aims? Which strategies are used in order to conduct research in digital archaeology and archive research data in Germany?

The three main categories are further subdivided into smaller sections that explain the iDAI.world’s fields of use in a more detailed fashion. Here, one can also get access to projects that the DAI is or was involved in. The projects in the iDAI.world are continuously updated.

articles.headline: NARA and Rakob portal – two new portals of the DAI Rome Department on North Africa

teaser.content:
Two new portals on the bequest of Rakob and the North African Research Archive (NARA) are available in the object database iDAI.objects/Arachne.

Together, both portals offer a multilingual interface for a central cultural archive of the DAI, Rome Department that is concerned with archaeology, architecture and cultural history of North Africa.The Rakob portal is dedicated to the bequest of Friedrich Rakob (1931-2007) who, while working as a research in Roman architectural research at the Rome Department from 1962-1996, gained importance due to his research in the Maghreb region, especially in the northern Tunisian cities of Carthago and Chimtou. By funding of the Foreign Ministry of Germany, photographs, drawings and documents of his that were kept at the Rome Department, could be digitized and made available.

As of 2019, Pelagios has moved on from being simply a project to being an own network, the Pelagios Networks, which is funded by the Mellon Foundation. Although the network does not have any funding powers, it does present itself with a constitution. The network is formed by around 20 members so far that are bound to the network by a memorandum of understanding. The former working groups are now represented in the six activities fulfilled by Pelagios: annotation, collaboration, gazetteer, pedagogy, registry and visualization.

The site of Pergamon, located northwest of the modern city of Bergama in Turkey, rises above the Bakirçay Plain. As the capital of the Hellenistic Attalid dynasty Pergamon was one of the most prominent urban centers of the ancient world. In addition to its political significance, the city was a cultural and religious center with a significant library, impressive temples, theaters and a gymnasium. The city later became capital of the Roman province of Asia, famous for its Asclepieion healing center.

World Heritage Site Pergamon
For more than 130 years archaeologists of the German Archaeological Institute have been working in the metropolis on the west coast of Turkey.

Landschaftsarchäologische Untersuchungen in Phokis/Mittelgriechenland

Seit 2018 erforschen Prof. Dr. Katja Sporn (DAI Athen) und Prof. Dr. Peter Funke (Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster) in Kooperation mit Dr. Petros Kounouklas (Ephorie für Altertümer von Fthiotis und Eurytania) das Kephissostal im antiken Phokis. Der Kephissos ist mit 60 km Länge der wichtigste Fluss Zentralgriechenlands. Das Flusstal verläuft zwischen zwei großen Gebirgen, dem ca. 2500 m hohen Parnassos im Süden sowie dem Kallidromon im Norden. In der griechisch-römischen Antike war das breite, fruchtbare Tal ein strategisch wichtiges Durchgangsgebiet, das Schauplatz zahlreicher militärischer Auseinandersetzungen war.

articles.headline: AYDA a digital register of heritage monuments for Yemen

teaser.content:
Together with her team the archaeologist Dr. Iris Gerlach is working on a digital heritage information system for this crisis region, the Ancient Yemen Digital Atlas (AYDA). The digital project aims to contribute to the protection of Yemen’s cultural heritage.

Largely unnoticed by the world’s public the war in Yemen endangers the life of people and their cultural heritage. Over the past years safeguarding Yemen’s heritage has become more and more difficult due to the security conditions. Extensive pillaging and looting of sites has taken place at several locations. “Unauthorized construction work has been carried out at the antique sites and stones have been stolen. Museum pillages occur primarily in the southern part of the country. In addition, serious war damage can be observed. This is a varied mixture of different things.”, says Dr. Iris Gerlach, director of the Sana’a Office of the German Archaeological Institute.
